channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Undecided Syrians Could Tip Balance of Rebellion
item.description: In Syria, each side has bloodied the other while many stay on the sidelines, and a contingent of supporters feels obligated to stick with the government even as their doubts grow.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: A destroyed home in Aleppo, Syria. Some Syrians say they feel trapped by the government and the violence engulfing the country, but are afraid to take sides in the rebellion.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: After Years in Solitary, an Austere Life as Uruguay’s President
item.description: José Mujica, a former guerrilla who took office in 2010, shuns opulence, donates most of his salary and lives modestly, as he says a leader of a proper democracy should.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Matilde Campodonico for The New York Times
item.media:description: José Mujica shunned the presidential palace for his modest home on Montevideo’s outskirts.

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
item.description: A round-up of news from across India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Crackdowns Make Fleeing North Korea Harder
item.description: The tightening of controls at the border led to a fall of about 44 percent decrease over the previous year in the number of North Koreans defecting to South Korea in 2012.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: The Rev. Kim Seung-eun at his church in Cheonan, a center for activists who help smuggle refugees from North Korea.

item.title: Digital Technology Is Making Its Mark in Cuba
item.description: Using inexpensive digital technology, movie directors in Cuba are laying the foundations for an industry independent of the state apparatus of the Castro years.
item.dc:creator: By VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:credit: Jose Goitia for The New York Times
item.media:description: The director Carlos Lechuga at the International Festival of New Latin American Cinema in Havana.

item.title: Anglicans Open a Path to Bishopric for Gay Men
item.description: The Church of England said Friday that gay clergymen in civil partnerships could become bishops as long as they vowed to remain celibate.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL

item.title: Leaders of Sudan and South Sudan in Ethiopia for Talks
item.description: The two nations have been locked in a tense dispute over borders, territory and oil since the south split off and became its own country 18 months ago.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: John Sheardown, Canadian Who Sheltered Americans in Tehran, Dies at 88
item.description: Mr. Sheardown, a diplomat, played a consequential role in the “Canadian caper” during the Iran hostage crisis, though his role was unmentioned in the recent movie “Argo.”
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: John Sheardown, right, with Kenneth Taylor, the former Canadian ambassador to Iran.

item.title: Letter from Europe: A Struggle With Identity and Racism
item.description: Bananas being hurled at black soccer players in different parts of Europe and a Russian fan club's open letter saying it would not accept dark-skinned players highlight an unresolved uneasiness.
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: China Says Reporter for The Times Was Not Expelled
item.description: A Foreign Ministry spokeswoman said Chris Buckley’s visa application had been filed incorrectly and foreign news outlets were to blame for his departure from mainland China.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Congolese Peace Talks Threaten to Stall
item.description: Negotiations between rebels and the government, now seem in danger of not happening, as both sides appear to be rearming.
item.dc:creator: By JOSH KRON

item.title: Gas Station Attack Kills at Least 10 in Syria
item.description: An explosion in the Syrian capital early Friday added to fears that attackers were focusing on places where civilians congregate in order to inflict maximum casualties.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: Firefighters examined the damage left by a bomb attack on a gas station in the Damascus neighborhood of Barzeh on Friday, the second assault this week on people who sought fuel.

item.title: Exports of U.S. Gas May Fall Short of High Hopes
item.description: Global demand for natural gas — which would be shipped from the United States in a condensed form — could taper off by the time new and costly export terminals are ready.
item.dc:creator: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.media:credit: Michael Stravato for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cheniere Energy is building a facility for liquefied natural gas in Cameron Parish, La. It is the first to secure an export license.

item.title: Debit and Credit Card Purchases Shut Down at Vatican
item.description: The move follows a Bank of Italy decision based on concerns over financial accountability and money-laundering controls.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and HARVEY MORRIS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 5
item.description: Fiscal woes and American power; Google's challenge in Europe; an inside view of Afghan rage; tighter borders for North Koreans.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: State to Make Addicts Get Help
item.description: The authorities in São Paulo, Brazil’s most populous state, said they would start detaining addicts of crack cocaine and sending them against their will to treatment centers.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Yuval Diskin, Former Israeli Security Chief, Calls Netanyahu a Poor Leader
item.description: Prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu placed his own interests over Israel’s on issues including Iran and the Palestinian conflict, charged Yuval Diskin, the former head of the domestic security service.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Afghanistan Frees Detainees Before Karzai Trip to U.S.
item.description: President Hamid Karzai’s government in Afghanistan released 80 people as part of an effort to assert sovereignty over detainees, a source of tension with the United States.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and HABIB ZAHORI
item.media:description: Afghan men prayed in Kabul on Friday after their release from prison. Eighty detainees formerly held by the United States were freed by Afghan authorities.

item.title: Seizures of Illegal Ivory Are Rising in Hong Kong
item.description: Customs officials announced on Friday their third large seizure of smuggled ivory in less than three months, saying they had intercepted 779 elephant tusks valued at around $1.4 million.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER
item.media:description: The smuggled ivory shipment confiscated by custom officials in Hong Kong was valued at around $1.4 million.

item.title: Japanese Envoy Tries to Mend Ties With South KoreaJapanese Envoy Tries to Mend Ties With South Korea
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan reached out to South Korea’s incoming president, Park Geun-hye, on Friday by sending a special envoy to Seoul.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: The Japanese envoy, Fukushiro Nukaga, left, met South Korea’s incoming president, Park Geun-hye, in Seoul on Friday.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Venezuela: Constitution Said to Permit Chávez to Take Oath After Term Starts
item.description: President Hugo Chávez can be sworn in after the start of his new term, which is set by the Constitution for Jan. 10, Vice President Nicolás Maduro said Friday night.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Iraqi Prime Minister Faces More Calls for Resignation
item.description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has come under fire for measures that some lawmakers and political opponents see as an attempt to monopolize power ahead of provincial elections.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN and CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.media:description: Sunni Muslims shouted slogans and waved their national flag during a demonstration on Friday in Falluja in western Iraq.

item.title: Malala Yousafzai, Shot by Pakistani Taliban, Is Discharged From Hospital
item.description: Doctors said Malala Yousafzai, the teenager attacked for advocating girls’ education, would be staying with her family before returning for further surgery to her skull.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham, via Reuters
item.media:description: Malala Yousafzai leaving Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Birmingham, England, on Friday. Doctors said that she had made "excellent progress."

item.title: Pro Patria Fans’ Racism Prompts A.C. Milan Walkout, and Outrage
item.description: Showered with racist taunts, a player at an Italian exhibition led his team off the field — a first — and many hope that will have wide repercussions in sports.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Kevin-Prince Boateng, left, of A. C. Milan left the field during a match with Pro Patria because of racist chants from fans.

item.title: William Rees-Mogg, Former Editor of The Times of London, Dies at 84
item.description: Mr. Rees-Mogg was one of Britain’s most respected, if mercurial, conservative voices, rising to the defense of Richard Nixon as well as the Rolling Stones.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:credit: The Sunday Times, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: William Rees-Mogg with the paper he edited for 14 years.
